Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: The short-term association of ambient fine particulate air pollution with hypertension clinic visits: A multi-community study in Guangzhou, China.

AbstractText: The association of ambient fine particulate pollution with daily outpatient clinic visits (OCV) for hypertension in China remains to be investigated.

This study aimed to examine short-term impacts of exposure to fine particulate matter of aerodynamic diameter < 2.5μm (PM<sub>2.5</sub>) on daily OCV for hypertension, using a large-scale multi-center community database in Guangzhou, one of the most densely-populated cities in Southern China.

We collected a total of 28,548 individual records of OCV from 22 community healthcare facilities in Guangzhou from January 1st to May 7th 2020. Hourly data on air pollutants and daily information on meteorological factors were obtained. According to the World Health Organization air-quality guidelines, daily excessive concentration hours (DECH) was calculated. PM<sub>2.5</sub> daily mean, hourly-peak concentration and DECH were used as the exposure variables. Based on a case-time-control design, the Cox regression model was applied to evaluate the short-term relative risks (RR) of daily OCV for hypertension. Sensitivity analyses were conducted, with nitrogen dioxide, sulfur dioxide, carbon monoxide, and ozone being adjusted.

Daily mean and hourly-peak of PM<sub>2.5</sub> were significantly associated with daily OCV for hypertension, while weaker associations were observed for DECH. The estimated RRs at lag day 0 were 1.039 (95% confidence interval [CI]: 1.037, 1.040), 1.851 (95%CI: 1.814, 1.888), and 1.287 (95%CI: 1.276, 1.298), respectively, in association with a 1-unit increase in DECH, daily mean, and hourly-peak concentration of PM<sub>2.5</sub>. For the lagged effect, lag<sub>4</sub> models estimated the greatest RRs for PM<sub>2.5</sub> DECH and hourly-peak, whereas a lag<sub>2</sub> model produced the highest for PM<sub>2.5</sub> daily mean.

This study consolidates the evidence for a positive correlation between ambient PM<sub>2.5</sub> exposure and risks of hypertensive OCV. It also provides profound insight regarding planning for health services needs and establishing early environmental responses to the worsening air pollution in the communities.
